TopicTitle: Yay! Completed First Docking Mission (Career Mode)

Articles.Content:
I received my first orbital station and docking contracts, cool, let's do this! Launch up a simple "station" then launch the rendezvous rocket. As I am approaching I realize something; I forgot RCS, on both craft.

Well Dres, that sucks.

Revert flight? Nope. I ask myself, what would Jebadiah do?

So I set operator head space and timing, calibrated the ol' Mk I Eyeball and:

(Just had to share)

Well done!

I think we need some sort of "My first X in KSP!" thread.

- - - Updated - - -

'mission reports section'

Or that
Why do part sizes look weird? Tweakscale or perspective trick?

'mission reports section'

Sorry, didn't know there was a "Mission Reports" subfolder. Can a Mod move it for me please?

Thank you!

Why do part sizes look weird? Tweakscale or perspective trick?

The station is 2.5m parts. The tanks and adapter look to be from Modular Rocket Systems.

The station is 2.5m parts. The tanks and adapter look to be from Modular Rocket Systems.

That be it...
Congrats! My first unplanned RCS-free docking felt better than my first Mun landing

You... docked without RCS on your first docking? Or was it just your first docking contract? Because there's a slight difference.

Either way, congrats!

I received my first orbital station and docking contracts, cool, let's do this! Launch up a simple "station" then launch the rendezvous rocket. As I am approaching I realize something; I forgot RCS, on both craft.

Well, this couldn't have been easy. How difficult was it?

Docking small probes and landers without rcs is pretty easy but never done something so large.

One major benefit is that you can point both items towards each other.

Pre-1.x a lot of folks were doing minimalistic ion ships to Joolian moons - as I recall a significant number of them left the RCS behind. I find docking without entirely possible for small ships (once the magnets kick in, smaller is better), but past 10 tons or so I find myself really wanting RCS.

One big point on that is to have very low TWR on final approaches. You really don't want to kick in a couple of G's when you're only a few dozen meters away, and I've accidentally bumped 'Z' more than once under those conditions
